title: Off-road drivers were swept away by river, says man who tried to save them | The Bolton News
text:
A man who tried to save three men trapped in a submerged 4√ó4 vehicle said they were ‚Äúswept away‚Äù as they attempted to cross a river.
Emergency services including police, ambulance and a helicopter attended a location on the River Esk near Glaisdale shortly before midday on Thursday.
A 4√ó4 was recovered from the river by the fire service just after 3pm and three men found inside had died, North Yorkshire Police said.
Chris Ford, who lives nearby, told the PA news agency the men were part of an off-roading group when they crossed a ford on Rake Lane.
The river, swollen by heavy rain, swept them away and carried them around 400 yards downstream, he said.
Emergency services have been dealing with a serious incident on Thursday (28 December) involving a 4√ó4 vehicle in the River Esk near Glaisdale on the North York Moors üö®
Three men sadly died at the scene.
More information is available here ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/KgxPhHATO4 pic.twitter.com/AvDT3TiqCk
‚Äî North Yorkshire Police (@NYorksPolice) December 28, 2023
It came as Storm Gerrit caused flooding and travel chaos across the country throughout Wednesday and Thursday.
Mr Ford, a firewood salesman, was called to the scene to help recover the vehicle with his tractor and found it fully submerged beneath the water, he said.
He and two others used tractors to pull the 4√ó4 on to the riverbank, he said.
Police said another man, who attempted to help those trapped in the car, was pulled from the river and needed medical treatment.
Mr Ford told PA: ‚ÄúThere was a ford they were going over and they were swept down 400 yards.
‚ÄúThey were part of an off-road club.
‚ÄúI went down with my tractor. There was a couple of vehicles ‚Äì one parked up.
‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt see the (other) vehicle. It was 3ft beneath the water.
‚ÄúI helped get it out on to the riverbank with three other tractors.‚Äù
Two other locals, Rosie and Andrew Dale, said they were with Mr Ford when he got the call to help.
They said they saw several 4√ó4 vehicles pass their home in the direction of the ford shortly before the incident.
Mrs Dale said ‚Äúnobody local‚Äù would attempt to cross the ford in the current conditions.
The area is popular with 4√ó4 drivers, she said, adding: ‚ÄúIn the summer you get 10 of them at a time.‚Äù
A spokesperson for North Yorkshire Police said: ‚ÄúLocalised conditions across our area are making driving hazardous.
‚ÄúRoads are particularly badly affected around the River Esk, to the north of the county, as we have seen with the tragic incident near Glaisdale.
‚ÄúThere was another incident at nearby Houlsyke at 12.49pm when a car got stuck in flood water and another at Kirby Wiske in Hambleton at 2.35pm.
‚ÄúThankfully, the occupants of both vehicles were brought to safety.
‚ÄúThe key advice is to consider whether your journey is necessary.
‚ÄúPlease avoid driving through any kind of standing or moving flood water if you possibly can.‚Äù
Witnesses to the incident at Glaisdale are urged to call North Yorkshire Police on 101, option 4, quoting reference NYP-28122023-0146.
